resources.string: Cat with glasses holding a cup
O2 flow speed in liters per minute

You only carry the material that fits in the backpacks.

The cylinder is a type D and you know that the doctor will ask you for ten or fifteen liters per minute.

How long will the cylinder last you?

You must take a patient with respiratory failure to another referral hospital.

It is a 45-minute drive and the patient needs 6 liters per minute.

Do you have enough oxygen for the transfer?

Open the valve and check the pressure.

In this example the pressure gauge shows 6000 kPa and also 870 psi.

Look at the unit.

TempO2 will calculate the remaining oxygen time by adjusting the following parameters:

1. Write the pressure value: In this case 6000.

2. Choose the pressure unit: In this case kPa.

3. Choose the flow rate you plan to use (L/min). For our second scenario: 6 L/min.

4. Choose a cylinder format: In this case: 10 L.
The remaining time is 1 hour and 23 minutes.\n\nYou will be able to make the secondary transfer even with room for unforeseen events.

TempO2 is an informative and educational tool. It should not be used as the sole basis for medical, supply or safety decisions. The data may not be accurate and is not a substitute for advice from qualified professionals. The use of this application is the responsibility of the user.
